command: WITHHELD_FOR_SAFETY - mshta variant: local HTA from user-writable directory invoked from PowerShell
explanation: Represents proxy execution where PowerShell launches mshta to run a locally staged HTA from a permissive path (e.g., user profile or ProgramData), maintaining the signed-host execution chain.
rationale_steps: Stage an HTA in a writable path to avoid privileged write requirements
Invoke mshta from PowerShell to execute the local HTA content
Leverages trust in Microsoft-signed hosts to blend with legitimate activity
Detect via command-line logging (4688/Sysmon EID 1) and unusual HTA launches from non-standard locations
Restrict HTA execution paths and script hosts via WDAC/AppLocker

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: No concrete command string is provided—only a descriptive placeholder—so it is not runnable or parseable as-is.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: While PowerShell launching mshta to run a local HTA is a plausible proxy execution pattern, it aligns with Signed Binary Proxy Execution (T1218.005) rather than System Script Proxy Execution (T1216).
